titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0062, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Four gospels in Greek. Ammonian section numbers and lectionary incipits in the margins. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 60.

initials.p: Monograms in red within circular frames (28-45 mm, fols. 36r, 58v). Major initial Ε at the opening of Luke in red (90 mm). Minor initials set off from the text in red.

foliation.p: 1-117. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil.

collation.p: Of the 15 extant quires, quire 10 beginning at Matthew 9:6 belongs between those currently numbered 1 and 2, and quire 11 beginning at Mark 7:37 should follow quire 6. It is believed the manuscript's initial quires each contained 8 leaves. Estimate of content lost: kephalaia tables for Matthew and John, and an unknown number of leaves containing the text of Matthew 7:21- 9:6; 12:42-13:15; Luke 19:15-24:53; and John 1:1-3:3, 6:64-21:25.

physDesc.dimensions: Written space 150 x 95 mm (fol. 17r). Each column is 150 x 42 mm with a space of 11 mm between.

layout.p: 2 columns, 30 lines (variants of 26 to 32 lines). Ruling with hard point. Pricking in outer margins.

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in black ink (fading and flaking).
Punctuation includes high point, comma, marks of interrogation and elision. Quotation marks next to lines of Old Testament quotes are placed in the left margin.
Errors are corrected either by erasure, or with various reference marks in cases of omission.

textDivisions.p: Lections noted in the margins with the indicators αρχε (beginning) and τελος (end).

condition.p: Parchment speckled and cockled. Discolored edges. Some tears and holes. Overwriting of faded text with black ink. Water and grease stains.

binding.p: Covers lost. Quires stitched together with cord.

origin.p: The manuscript is dated to the 13th century, and is judged to have been written in the Balkan Peninsula.

provenance.p: Medieval to late 19th century provenance unknown. Belonged to Sir Edwin Pears (1835-1919), British barrister and historian. He is said to have purchased the manuscript in the 1880s in Constantinople, the present-day Istanbul, Turkey, wherein he practiced law in the consular courts for over forty years.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago from Maggs Bros. (London), date unknown.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

msItem.summary: Matthew (begins at 2:1 with εν ημεραις ηρωδων). Subscription and verse.
Luke (ends at 19:15 with αυτω τους δουλ[ους]).
John (begins at 3:3 with και ειπεν αυτω αμην αμην and ends at 6:64 with οι μη πιστευοντες).
